practice.inNumerator.mainProblem.latestText: Consider the equation <block-math/> Solve this equation for <inline-math/> and simplify the result as much as possible.

practice.inNumerator.step1.problem.oldText: Move all factors on the side of <inline-math/> to the other side, except <inline-math/> itself, to isolate <inline-math/>.
practice.inNumerator.step1.problem.latestText: Move all factors on the side of <inline-math/> to the other side, except <inline-math/> itself.

practice.inNumerator.step1.solution.latestText: We move the factor <inline-math/> to the other side, where it turns into a division.<check><on-false> We also move the factor <inline-math/> to the other side, where it becomes a multiplication.</on-false></check> All together, we wind up with <block-math/> Note that <inline-math/> has been isolated.

practice.inNumerator.step2.problem.latestText: Simplify the result for <inline-math/> as much as possible.

practice.inNumerator.step2.solution.latestText: First we write the fraction as a division between numbers, which is <block-math/> We then simplify this fraction by canceling a factor <inline-math/> in both the numerator and the denominator. This results in the final solution, <block-math/> It is not possible to simplify this any further.

practice.inNumerator.step3.problem.oldText: Check your solution by inserting it into the original equation, simplifying both sides as much as possible, and seeing if they reduce to the same result.
practice.inNumerator.step3.problem.latestText: Check the solution for <inline-math/>: insert it into the original equation and simplify each side as much as possible.

practice.inNumerator.step3.solution.oldText: The left side of the equation becomes, in order, <block-math/> Similarly, the right side will be <block-math/> This is the same number, which shows that the solution that we have found is indeed a solution to the given equation.
practice.inNumerator.step3.solution.latestText: <par><check><on-true>The left side of the original equation is already a number without <inline-math/> so no substitution is necessary. <check><on-true>It can still be simplified into <block-math/></on-true><on-false>It also cannot be simplified, so it remains as is, being <inline-math/>.</on-false></check></on-true><on-false>Substituting <inline-math/> into the left side of the original equation gives us <block-math/> Simplifying the resulting fraction turns it into <block-math/></on-false></check></par><par><check><on-true>The right side of the original equation is already a number without <inline-math/> so no substitution is necessary. <check><on-true>It can still be simplified into <block-math/></on-true><on-false>It also cannot be simplified, so it remains as is, being <inline-math/>.</on-false></check></on-true><on-false>Substituting <inline-math/> into the right side of the original equation gives us <block-math/> Simplifying the resulting fraction turns it into <block-math/></on-false></check></par><par>Both sides of the equation reduce to the same number, which means that the solution is correct.</par>

practice.inDenominator.mainProblem.latestText: Consider the equation <block-math/> Move the factor <inline-math/> to the other side. (Also make sure that there are no fractions of fractions in the final result.)

crossExerciseFeedback.unbalancedEquation.latestText: The two sides of the equation should in the end be the same. This value is not equal to the other one.
